Issue Title: Image Media thumbnail alt text cannot be changed without reuploading the image
Description: Image Media thumbnail alt text cannot be changed without reuploading the image
acr_note: Users with disabilities relying on screen readers may be unable to accurately describe images displayed as thumbnails due to the lack of editable alternative text. This creates a barrier to understanding the content and effectively utilizing the image media.
dev_note: This issue indicates a critical accessibility problem. The current system prevents users from providing descriptive alt text for thumbnails, directly violating WCAG 1.1.1 Level A guidelines regarding text alternatives for non-text content.
thread_tldr: The thumbnail alt text for image media cannot be changed without reuploading, causing accessibility issues for screen reader users who cannot determine the image content. A patch applying a one-line change has been submitted to Drupal 10, but it requires review and testing.
thread_problem: Initial report only. Users relying on screen readers are unable to access the alt text for image media thumbnails, preventing them from understanding the content of the images. Several contributors have discussed the issue, with a recent patch submitted to Drupal 10 which modifies the image upload process to allow alt text changes. However, no testing has occurred and the patch's suitability remains uncertain. No evidence of follow-up or resolution.
thread_timeline: #1 sourav_paul: Initial report filed. #2 smustgrave: Suggested testing.
thread_links: - [WCAG 1.1.1 - Non-text Content](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/non-text-content.html): Relevant WCAG success criterion.

Issue Title: Pager template fails accessibility tests for Ellipsis ("...")
Description: Pager template fails accessibility tests for Ellipsis ("...")
acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty interpreting the pagination controls within the Pager template due to the absence of appropriate visual cues and semantic structure. This can impede their ability to navigate and understand the number of pages available.
dev_note: The issue report indicates a failure of accessibility tests related to the ellipsis ("...") used in the Pager template. This likely stems from a lack of semantic HTML and/or insufficient ARIA attributes to convey the pagination state to screen reader users.
thread_tldr: The ellipsis in the pager template violates WCAG 2.2.3 (No heading level skipped) by creating a low-perceivable navigation experience. The issue is currently under review and awaiting a solution.
thread_problem: Initial report only. The issue was reported by a user, and the proposed solution was a patch that added an aria-label to the ellipsis. However, the design system guidelines (USWDS) recommend using the standard pagination component with semantic HTML, effectively bypassing the need for an aria-label in this context. No further discussion or testing has occurred since the initial report.
thread_timeline: #1 user: Filed initial accessibility report.
thread_links: - [USWDS Pagination](https://design-system.service.gov.uk/components/pagination/) - [WCAG 2.2.3 No heading level skipped](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/headings-and-text.html)

Issue Title: Radios element missing "required" attribute
Description: Radios element missing "required" attribute
acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may be unable to determine if a radio button group is required, potentially leading to incorrect selections and frustration. The absence of a clearly communicated requirement hinders usability and could result in data inaccuracies.
dev_note: The reported issue – the missing “required” attribute on radio buttons – does not inherently create an accessibility barrier. WCAG does not dictate a specific attribute to enforce requirement for radio buttons; instead, it relies on clear visual and programmatic cues. To address this, focus on providing clear visual indicators of required fields, such as a red asterisk or a distinct styling change when a radio button is selected.  More importantly, ensure the form itself is properly associated with a submission target, and that the submission process explicitly validates that all required fields have been populated. If the requirement is part of a larger form, ensure the form’s overall required status is clearly conveyed.  If there are programmatic requirements, utilize form validation techniques (client-side and server-side) to enforce the requirement. Avoid using ARIA attributes to mimic “required” as this can conflict with screen reader behavior and is generally considered bad practice.
thread_tldr: The "required" attribute was removed from the radio element, creating a potential accessibility issue for users relying on form validation. The issue is currently stalled with no recent activity.
thread_problem: An assertion for the `fieldgroupattribute` was removed by commit `b0953653` between comments #85 and #86. This means the attribute, which was previously tested and deemed functional, is now untested and potentially broken. No evidence of follow-up or resolution exists.
thread_timeline: #85 acbramley: Issue summary updated. #86 needs-review-queue-bot: Status: Needs work. #97 deepakkm: made their first commit to this issue’s fork. #98 acbramley: Issue summary updated.
thread_links: - [WCAG 2.2 Level AA](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/): Accessibility guidelines. - [ARIA Specifications](https://w3.org/TR/wai-aria/):  Accessible Rich Internet Applications.

dev_note: The request to add an exposed filter to the Taxonomy overview view suggests a need to improve the user’s ability to narrow down the displayed items.  The first step is to assess whether a native HTML filter control (e.g., `<select>`, `<input type="search">`) can achieve the desired functionality.
thread_tldr: The taxonomy filter feature allows users to filter taxonomy terms, but doesn't currently support translation of those terms. The issue is currently awaiting a product manager review to determine the best course of action.

Description: CKEditor 5 text area doesn't have appropriate aria-label for screen reader
acr_note: Users who rely on screen readers may experience difficulty identifying and operating the CKEditor 5 text area due to a lack of a clear, descriptive `aria-label` attribute. This creates a barrier to accessing and interacting with the text editing component.
dev_note: The reported issue indicates a missing or inadequate `aria-label` for the CKEditor 5 text area. The primary solution is to ensure the text area element has a meaningful `aria-label` attribute that accurately describes its function.
thread_tldr: CKEditor 5 text area aria-label is incorrectly overriding the field label, causing confusion for screen reader users. The issue is currently stalled with no recent activity.

Several contributors have discussed this, with proposed solutions involving repositioning the aria-label to the field wrapper. No patch or pull request has been actively applied as of this analysis.

Description: Accessing a toolbar sub-menu seems to result in a keyboard trap
acr_note: Users may be unable to navigate away from a toolbar sub-menu when using a keyboard. This prevents keyboard users from continuing their task or accessing other parts of the application.
dev_note: This issue likely indicates a lack of proper keyboard trap handling within the toolbar sub-menu implementation.  The primary focus should be on ensuring the sub-menu's focus management correctly allows for navigation away after selection.

Issue Title: Use ARIA disclosure pattern for submenu buttons in vertical toolbar orientation
Description: Use ARIA disclosure pattern for submenu buttons in vertical toolbar orientation
acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may encounter difficulty identifying and interacting with submenu options presented as buttons within a vertical toolbar. The lack of explicit ARIA roles and states on these buttons can hinder discoverability and navigation, potentially isolating users from related content.
dev_note: The issue describes a common challenge with vertical toolbar navigation. The recommended approach is to prioritize semantic HTML solutions. Specifically, consider using `<button>` elements with appropriate `aria-haspopup` and `aria-expanded` attributes to simulate a dropdown menu.
thread_tldr: The toolbar submenu button lacks ARIA attributes, causing accessibility issues for users navigating with screen readers. The issue is currently stalled due to lack of recent activity. A fix is needed to ensure proper screen reader support.
thread_problem: The issue stems from the absence of ARIA attributes on the submenu buttons within the vertical toolbar.  Multiple users, including Benjifisher and Kentr, have identified this as a barrier, with Kentr referencing the `claro_system_module_invoked_library_info_alter()` function as the root cause. No recent testing or refinement of a solution has occurred. WCAG 2.2.A ARIA Persistent ARIA Roles and States is potentially affected.

Issue Title: Assess JavaScript behaviours for WCAG 2.1 Pointer Cancellation
Description: Assess JavaScript behaviours for WCAG 2.1 Pointer Cancellation
acr_note: Users relying on keyboard navigation or assistive technologies may experience difficulty interacting with interactive elements if JavaScript behaviours related to pointer cancellation are not implemented accessibly. This can lead to a degraded user experience and potential exclusion.
dev_note: The issue title, "Assess JavaScript behaviours for WCAG 2.1 Pointer Cancellation," is referencing a WCAG 2.1 requirement, but the relevant standard for pointer cancellation is now WCAG 2.2.  The core accessibility concern is that JavaScript-driven pointer cancellation disrupts expected interaction patterns. Developers should prioritize a semantic HTML structure that supports the intended user flow. If JavaScript is *required* to achieve the desired interaction, then use ARIA attributes judiciously to provide alternative ways for users to trigger the same behaviour. Specifically, investigate if the pointer cancellation is truly necessary – often, a well-designed interaction can be achieved with standard keyboard navigation. Consider using `role="dialog"` and `role="alert"` with appropriate ARIA attributes to provide focus management for modal dialogs created by JavaScript.  Avoid directly interfering with the natural pointer cancellation behavior of the browser.  Utilize `focus()` calls strategically to ensure keyboard focus lands in the appropriate element after a cancellation.
thread_tldr: The issue of assessing JavaScript behaviors for WCAG 2.1 Pointer Cancellation has received minimal engagement. A patch has been proposed, but it's currently in a hidden branch and hasn't been formally reviewed or merged. The status needs review and further action is required.
thread_problem: Andrewmacpherson reported concerns about JavaScript behaviors impacting WCAG 2.1 Pointer Cancellation, specifically relating to touch and keypress events. A patch (2.49 KB) was proposed that switches the default event from click to mouseup and adds a keypress handler, aiming to improve keyboard accessibility.  The patch is currently in a hidden branch, awaiting review.

Since that is past I am removing the tag. #19 deepakwerma: StatusFileSizenew2958654-wcag-pointer-cancellation.patch2.49 KBProposed patch for WCAG 2.5.2 Pointer Cancellation #21 deepakwerma: deepakwermachanged the visibility of the branch2958654-assess-javascript-behaviourstohidden.

Issue Title: W3C Validation: required attribute not allowed on fieldset tag
Description: W3C Validation: required attribute not allowed on fieldset tag
acr_note: The issue reports a validation error regarding the `required` attribute on a `<fieldset>` tag. While W3C validation may flag this, the current understanding of web standards indicates that using the `required` attribute directly on a `<fieldset>` is not a valid or recommended practice for accessibility. This can potentially hinder screen reader users’ ability to understand the grouping of related form controls.
dev_note: The reported issue is related to a validation check, not a fundamental accessibility barrier. While some validation tools might flag the `required` attribute on a `<fieldset>`, this is not a violation of WCAG guidelines. The semantic meaning of a `<fieldset>` is to group related form controls, and this functionality is already achieved through its child elements. Therefore, no action is required to address this. Developers should ensure that form controls within a `<fieldset>` have their own `required` attributes as appropriate for their individual purpose, rather than relying on the fieldset to enforce required status. Using the `required` attribute on individual input fields is the correct and standard way to ensure data integrity and accessibility.
thread_tldr: The issue report concerns the disallowed use of the `required` attribute on a `fieldset` tag, which is flagged as a W3C validation error. While a patch was submitted and reviewed, the issue remains "Needs review" with no further activity.
thread_problem: The issue report details a W3C validation error related to the use of the `required` attribute on a `fieldset` tag.  Shamir.vs submitted a patch (#12) addressing this, and Liam Morland made a merge request incorporating the patch and a related fix for the date range input issue. However, the status remains “Needs review” with no further testing or confirmation of resolution.
thread_timeline: #1 zakiya: Created the initial accessibility issue. #2 zakiya: Referenced related issues and WCAG 2.2. #4 shamir.vs: Submitted a patch to remove the `required` attribute from `fieldset`. #9 lisotton: Provided a patch with assertions for when and when not to appear. #11 avpaderno: Noted the patch needs review. #12 ranjith_kumar_k_u: Re-rolled #9 patch. #19 rhithwik: Suggested a conditional fix for date range inputs. #22 liam morland: Made a merge request and noted WCAG 4.1.1 removal. #23 smustgrave: Suggested adding simple assertions. #24 kpaxman: Raised the question of generic fixes for other invalid elements. #25 liam morland: Rerolled the issue.

Issue Title: Exposed filters with exposed operators are missing accessible names
Description: Exposed filters with exposed operators are missing accessible names
acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may not be able to identify or interact with filters and their operators when they are presented without associated accessible names. This lack of descriptive information prevents users from effectively utilizing the filtering functionality, hindering their ability to navigate and understand the content presented by the application.
dev_note: The issue reports missing accessible names for exposed filters and operators. To address this, developers should prioritize using semantic HTML elements to structure and label these controls. Specifically, use `<button>` elements for operators and `<label>` elements connected to the corresponding filter inputs via the `for` attribute. If semantic HTML cannot adequately convey the function of the filter or operator, then use ARIA attributes to provide descriptive names and roles.
thread_tldr: The issue reports missing accessible names for exposed filter operators, specifically numeric values, within Drupal forms. The issue is currently marked as “Needs review” and awaiting further action.
thread_problem: The issue, initially reported by kentr, describes a lack of accessible names associated with exposed filter operators, particularly numeric values, when used within exposed filters.  Kentr's subsequent comments highlight this and suggest using a tool like Axe to detect named elements.  No patches or technical fixes have been implemented.
thread_timeline: #1 kentr: Created issue and provided initial summary. #3 kentr: Added title and tags, including “Needs tests.” #5 kentr: Status changed to “Needs review.” #8 acbramley: Status changed to “Needs work” and offered a related issue. #9 cboyden: Added more details and screenshots, highlighting the issue across multiple exposed filters/operators.

Issue Title: The “reduce motion” setting in the operating system should be respected
Description: The “reduce motion” setting in the operating system should be respected
acr_note: Users with motion sensitivities may experience discomfort or distraction if the website’s animations and transitions do not align with their operating system’s “reduce motion” setting. This creates a barrier to accessing the content for users who have adjusted their system settings for reduced visual motion.
dev_note: This issue centers on respecting the user’s operating system’s “reduce motion” preference. The primary goal is to prevent animations and transitions from impacting users with vestibular disorders or similar sensitivities.
thread_tldr: The issue is reporting respect for the operating system’s “reduce motion” setting. Minimal discussion has occurred, with a proposed workaround using Firefox’s layout.frame_rate setting and a related CSS transition. The issue remains “Needs review” with no recent activity.
thread_problem: The reported accessibility barrier is the Drupal interface not correctly respecting the user’s operating system “reduce motion” setting, potentially causing distraction or discomfort for users with sensitivities. Marcoliver made their first commit to this issue’s fork, experimenting with CSS transitions to control the frame rate and scope of duration resets.
thread_timeline: #1 rkoller: Created the initial issue. #2 charles belov: Suggested using layout.frame_rate set to 3 in Firefox as a workaround. #6 marcoliver: Opened an MR.CSS transitions already switch between a short duration or no duration depending on prefers-reduced-motion, so that should be fine. #7 finnsky: Confirmed minimal engagement, left the issue as “Needs review”.

Issue Title: CKEditor 5: scroll jump after dialog close
Description: CKEditor 5: scroll jump after dialog close
acr_note: Users may experience a jarring and disorienting transition when a CKEditor 5 dialog is closed, resulting in the cursor jumping to an unexpected location within the editor. This disrupts the user's workflow and potentially hinders their ability to accurately position the cursor for continued editing.
dev_note: This issue likely stems from a lack of proper focus management when closing dialogs within CKEditor 5. The standard approach is to ensure that the focus remains on the element that triggered the dialog closure (e.g., the dialog itself, or the editor's main content area).  CKEditor 5 should automatically handle focus restoration.
thread_tldr: CKEditor 5 dialog closing triggers a scroll jump. While a workaround exists via a media insert, it introduces a new UI issue. The issue is currently postponed and requires further manual testing.
thread_problem: The issue reports a scroll jump occurring immediately after closing the CKEditor 5 dialog.  edwardsay identified this behavior and a workaround was suggested involving inserting media via the Insert Media button, which mitigates the scroll but introduces a separate UI issue. The issue remains active and requires manual testing.

Issue Title: [drupalMedia] Using the Insert Media button causes the window to scroll to the bottom of the page

acr_note: Users attempting to utilize the Insert Media button within the Drupal Media module experience a visually disruptive scrolling event, causing the browser window to scroll to the bottom of the page. This can hinder the ability to interact with subsequent page elements and negatively impacts the user experience.
dev_note: This issue likely stems from a conflict between the Insert Media button’s behavior and the page’s initial viewport size or scrolling behavior. Here’s a prioritized approach to address this:

A patch (#5) has been submitted by gouthamraon, and has received positive feedback from multiple users, but the issue remains unresolved and needs further review.

However, this is not consistently confirmed, and the issue is currently marked as "Postponed (maintainer needs more info)". The core issue relates to potential issues with CKEditor5 and focus management.

Issue Title: [PLAN] Accessibility review for new Navigation bar
Description: [PLAN] Accessibility review for new Navigation bar
acr_note: The navigation bar lacks sufficient semantic structure, potentially hindering screen reader users’ ability to understand and navigate the site. This could lead to confusion and difficulty in locating desired content.
dev_note: The issue title is extremely vague and requires further clarification.  The developer needs to provide details about the specific navigation bar in question.  Assuming the navigation bar consists of links, the first step is to ensure each link element has the correct semantic HTML structure – using `<nav>` for the overall navigation area and `<a href="...">` for individual links.  Each link must have an appropriate `role="navigation"` attribute on the `<nav>` element.  Ensure sufficient color contrast between link text and the background for users with low vision.  If the navigation includes dropdown menus, utilize `<button>` elements with appropriate ARIA attributes (e.g., `role="menu"`, `aria-haspopup="true"`, `aria-expanded="false"` initially) to manage the state and behavior of the dropdown. Avoid relying on JavaScript alone to implement dropdown functionality; ensure keyboard accessibility and focus management within the dropdown. If native HTML elements cannot be used effectively, then implement ARIA attributes as a last resort, adhering strictly to WAI-ARIA guidelines.
thread_tldr: The mobile expanded sidebar modal overlay has invalid ARIA attributes, potentially causing screen reader users to experience difficulties navigating and accessing content. A recent comment proposes integrating "reduce motion" settings to respect user preferences.
thread_problem: Initial report only.  The issue involves screen reader accessibility within the mobile expanded sidebar modal overlay.  Recent feedback suggests a mismatch in ARIA attributes ('aria-expanded' is missing) impacting screen reader navigation. No evidence of follow-up or resolution.
thread_timeline: #1 rkoller: Added #3551528: Mobile expanded sidebar modal overlay has invalid ARIA attribute: aria-expanded to the issue summary.
thread_links: - [ARIA Attributes](https://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria/):  Relevant ARIA specification.

Issue Title: Add an API for hotkeys to Drupal core
Description: Add an API for hotkeys to Drupal core
acr_note: Users who rely on keyboard navigation may experience difficulty accessing content and functionality if a hotkey API is not implemented. This could create a barrier to interaction and limit usability for individuals with motor impairments or those who prefer keyboard-based workflows.
dev_note: This issue proposes adding a hotkey API to Drupal core. While the *intention* might be to improve accessibility, simply adding an API without considering accessibility best practices can actually *worsen* the experience. Drupal’s core strength lies in its existing semantic structure and accessibility features. The primary focus should be on ensuring existing core functionality is navigable via keyboard.
thread_tldr: The issue proposes an API for hotkeys in Drupal core to improve accessibility. Minimal discussion has occurred, with no patches or resolutions. The next step is unclear, requiring a product manager review and further investigation into potential conflicts with assistive technology.
thread_problem: rkoller initiated the discussion for a hotkeys API for Drupal core, citing potential benefits for power users and users with disabilities. mgifford and itmaybejj expressed support, highlighting the need for conflict resolution with AT key combinations and a centralized toggle for users. rkoller updated the issue summary and linked to a Google doc, but the link proved dead end.
thread_timeline: #1 rkoller: Created issue for hotkeys API. #2 mgifford: Provided supportive comment and raised AT conflict concern. #3 rkoller: Updated issue summary and linked to dead-end Google doc. #4 itmaybejj: Offered further suggestions regarding centralized control and global modifier keys. #5 rkoller: Updated the link to the google doc.
thread_links: - [WCAG 2.2.1 Keyboard – Availability](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/guidelines/gg12/keyboard.html): Addresses the need for keyboard accessibility.

Issue Title: Forms with required fields marked by asterisk do not have text explaining what the asterisk means
Description: Forms with required fields marked by asterisk do not have text explaining what the asterisk means
acr_note: Users who rely on screen readers may not understand the meaning of asterisks indicating required fields within forms. This lack of clear communication creates a barrier to successful form completion, potentially excluding users with disabilities.
dev_note: This issue highlights a critical lack of accessibility support for form instructions. The best approach is to use semantic HTML to convey required field status. Specifically, use the `<label>` element to associate directly with the input field.  The `<label>` element's `for` attribute must match the input's `id`.
thread_tldr: The issue of insufficient explanation for asterisk-marked required fields on forms remains unresolved. The current status is stalled with no recent activity; the next step is a review of the latest draft CR.
thread_problem: Initial report only. The accessibility barrier is the lack of text explaining the meaning of asterisks on required form fields, potentially hindering users with visual impairments. A draft CR (https://www.drupal.org/node/3544511) was created to address this, but no further discussion or testing appears to have occurred.

acr_note: Users may experience difficulty accessing the comment count and new comment functionality due to the lack of proper accessibility implementation. This potentially limits users’ ability to fully engage with the content and contribute meaningfully.
dev_note: The issue description indicates a lack of adherence to accessibility best practices for the “Add new comment” and "@count comments" links.  The primary focus should be on leveraging semantic HTML.
thread_tldr: The "Add new comment" and "@count comments" links exhibit accessibility issues, primarily related to lack of context for screen reader users. A patch was submitted to add visual context, but testing is lacking and the issue remains open, awaiting review and testing.

Issue Title: Support full-screen editing in CKEditor
Description: Support full-screen editing in CKEditor
acr_note: Users who require a distraction-free editing environment may find the absence of a full-screen mode a barrier to efficient content creation. This limitation could impact users with cognitive disabilities who benefit from focused workspaces and reduced visual distractions.
dev_note: The request for full-screen editing in CKEditor necessitates careful consideration of accessibility. Initially, evaluate if a modal dialog with maximized dimensions can adequately address the need. If this is insufficient, focus on ensuring the editor's content remains accessible within the modal. This involves: 1) Using semantic HTML for the modal’s content area (e.g., `<article>` or `<main>`). 2) Applying appropriate ARIA attributes *only* to enhance the experience when native HTML doesn’t provide sufficient context. Specifically, use `role="dialog"` on the modal and `aria-modal="true"` to communicate its modal nature. Ensure focus management within the modal using appropriate `tabindex` values and keyboard navigation. Consider using keyboard shortcuts for full-screen activation and exit.  Avoid adding unnecessary visual styling that might cause focus issues or negatively impact screen reader users.  Reference CKEditor’s documentation for modal implementation best practices, and consult WAI-ARIA 1.2 for proper attribute usage.
thread_tldr: The issue relates to the CKEditor full-screen mode, which appears to be functional but lacks clear accessibility controls and documentation. The community is currently awaiting a maintainer to review and refine the implementation.
thread_problem: Initial report (#1) indicates users are encountering difficulties using the CKEditor full-screen mode, specifically regarding keyboard navigation and screen reader compatibility.  #2, godotislate, has confirmed the issue locally and provided a screenshot.  #3, smustgrave, suggests a potential duplicate module exists in the CKEditor plugin repository. No further testing or refinement activity has been observed.
thread_timeline: #1 smustgrave: Reported the issue. #2 godotislate: Confirmed the issue locally and provided a screenshot. #3 smustgrave: Suggested a potential duplicate module.
thread_links: - [WCAG 2.1.1 Keyboard Accessibility](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/keyboard-keys-accel-nav): Relevant accessibility guideline.

Issue Title: Mobile version of Navigation should have focus trap
Description: Mobile version of Navigation should have focus trap
acr_note: The mobile navigation lacks a focus trap, potentially preventing keyboard users from easily accessing and navigating the site's content. This creates a barrier for users who rely on keyboard input, impacting their ability to effectively use the website.
dev_note: The request for a “focus trap” on the mobile navigation suggests the user wants to prevent keyboard focus from escaping the navigation menu while a user is actively using the keyboard to navigate.  This is typically achieved using the `tabindex` attribute, but it’s crucial to use this sparingly and only as a last resort.  The first step is to ensure the mobile navigation is logically structured with clear headings and sufficient keyboard focus order.  Specifically, ensure that the navigation items are focusable via the `Tab` key.  If focus *does* escape the navigation on mobile, consider using `tabindex="0"` on the navigation element and then carefully control the tab order using the `tabindex` attribute.  Apply `tabindex="0"` only to the navigation container and ensure it is the *first* element in the tab order. Test thoroughly with keyboard-only navigation to confirm the expected behavior.  Avoid using `tabindex` excessively as it can disrupt the natural tab order and create confusion for users.  Prioritize semantic HTML for keyboard navigation.
thread_tldr: The mobile navigation focus trap is reported but lacks a concrete solution. Mherchel has abstracted the logic to core level, awaiting review and potential integration with existing arrow navigation.
thread_problem: mherchel reported the need for a focus trap within the mobile navigation. Finnsky suggested merging with existing arrow navigation logic or moving it to core. Mherchel has abstracted the code to core, awaiting review. No patches or tests have been implemented. WCAG 2.4.11 Focus Not Obscured (Minimum) is referenced.
thread_timeline: #1 mherchel: Reported the issue. #8 mherchel: Suggested moving the logic to core. #11 mherchel: Reaffirmed the suggestion, stating it's achievable.

Issue Title: Submenu opened with hover does not close by Escape key when another menu item has focus
Description: Submenu opened with hover does not close by Escape key when another menu item has focus
acr_note: Users attempting to close a hover-opened submenu using the Escape key while another menu item has focus may experience difficulty. The current behavior prevents the submenu from closing, potentially leading to a frustrating and inaccessible user experience.
dev_note: This issue indicates a conflict between focus management and keyboard navigation within the submenu. The core problem is that the Escape key’s default behavior to close an element is being overridden when another focusable element exists within the page.

Issue Title: Elements in closed sidebar are focusable
Description: Elements in closed sidebar are focusable
acr_note: Users relying on keyboard navigation may be unable to access content within a closed sidebar. The lack of focusability prevents users with motor impairments or those navigating with assistive technologies from interacting with the sidebar’s elements.
dev_note: The reported issue indicates that elements within a closed sidebar are currently focusable, which violates WCAG 2.2 accessibility guidelines. The primary solution is to ensure that these elements are *not* focusable when the sidebar is closed. This can be achieved through several methods, prioritizing semantic HTML:
thread_tldr: The issue of focusable elements in closed sidebars has been partially resolved. A fix was implemented by shqshqnk to hide navigation links when the sidebar is collapsed, but a remaining issue exists regarding focus behavior on screen width changes in DevTools.
thread_problem: Initial report identified focusable elements within the closed sidebar. shqshqnk implemented a fix by adding `visibility: hidden` to the navigation links when the sidebar is collapsed, addressing the immediate issue. However, sandip reported that the toggle triggers function doesn't run on screen width change in DevTools.

Issue Title: Messages should have role=status instead of role=contentinfo
Description: Messages should have role=status instead of role=contentinfo
acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty understanding the status of messages if the `role="status"` attribute is not correctly applied. The current use of `role="contentinfo"` does not convey the intended meaning of a message’s state (e.g., success, error, warning) to assistive technologies, potentially leading to a confusing user experience.
dev_note: The core issue here is the correct semantic markup for a message indicating a status update.  `role="status"` is the appropriate ARIA role to use when a message represents a status update or notification.  This clearly communicates the element's purpose to assistive technologies.
thread_tldr: The system messages block is failing to announce due to a lack of proper ARIA attributes, specifically the role=status and aria-atomic attributes, resulting in accessibility issues for screen reader users when the page reloads. The latest attempted solution by thamas involved adding the role and aria attributes to the block’s template, but it was not tested. The issue is stalled with no recent activity.
thread_problem: Initial report only. cwilcox808 and thamas have identified that the system messages block is not properly announced after a page reload, which is a significant change in context for screen reader users.  The existing content of a live region is not announced after page reload (as that is not a content change of an existing page) per WCAG 2.2. Success Criterion 2.4.6 (Timeed Communication) may be relevant.
thread_timeline: #1 thamas: Reported the issue and initial attempt to fix it. #2 cwilcox808: Confirmed the issue and clarified the context change. #3 thamas: Updated the block template with role=status and aria-atomic.
thread_links: - [WCAG 2.2.6 Timeed Communication](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/timeed-communication.html) - [ARIA 1.1.1 Live Regions](https://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria/livereg#live-region)

Issue Title: System Menu blocks placed via Layout Builder can generate duplicate, invalid HTML ID attributes
Description: System Menu blocks placed via Layout Builder can generate duplicate, invalid HTML ID attributes
acr_note: System Menu blocks utilized within Layout Builder may result in duplicate HTML ID attributes. This could potentially lead to confusion for assistive technology users as the system may incorrectly interpret the duplicate IDs, impacting navigation and screen reader behavior.
dev_note: This issue likely stems from the Layout Builder’s method of generating IDs for System Menu blocks. The core problem is the potential for duplicate `id` attributes, violating HTML5 specification requirements.  The recommended fix prioritizes semantic HTML.
thread_tldr: The issue is a duplicate HTML ID attribute issue with Layout Builder, potentially causing link navigation problems. The community is stalled with no recent activity and a proposed fix is awaiting a CR.
thread_problem: The issue reports duplicate, invalid HTML ID attributes generated by Layout Builder when using System Menu blocks. Initial discussion centered around the potential for broken in-page links. daddison recently updated the twig template to use `clean_unique_idtwig` and added test coverage.
thread_timeline: #1 daddison: made their first commit to this issue’s fork. #2 daddison: I updatedhttps://git.drupalcode.org/project/drupal/-/merge_requests/6965to use|clean_unique_idtwig filter in the block  and updated test coverage. #3 smustgrave: Original concern of updating the the twig templates directly is back. We will need a CR as contrib and custom themes won't have that change.
